title: Friday, 8th January, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Hi there -- welcome to ML

PM

We haven't had one of these for a while

PM

Which is odd

11:01 am
PM

Given the news flow

PM

But let's fix that

PM

11:01 am
PM

Xiao Gang

PM

chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission

PM

But you knew that already

11:02 am
PM

So, Ive mentioned Bill Bishop before

PM

And his excellent Sinocism email

PM

You can sign up for it here: https://sinocism.com/

11:02 am
PM

Bill reckons Xiao is a dead man walking, professionally speaking

PM

And you can understand why

PM

Think we should join in here and sack Xiao

11:03 am
PM

But let me get a few pars from his email (written before the Chinese authorities removed the circuit breakers)

PM

Now that confidence has been totally destroyed by the boneheaded design and implementation of the circuit breaker mechanism. Even if policymakers now modify or remove that mechanism they have dug themselves such a deep credibility hole, domestically and overseas, that even in as populous a country as China there may be a shortage of suckers for stocks.

PM

Why do the policymakers keep making such stupid mistakes? Were they never that competent but just looked smart because there was so much low hanging fruit? Is China’s economy such a mess now that they have no good options left? Or has the policy-making process broken down under the centralization of decision-making under Xi Jinping, the diversion of attention to ideological work with shades of “better red than expert” amidst a cadre cultural revolution, the exodus of experienced financial regulators to both better opportunities in China’s financial sector and interrogations in padded cells, as well as the suffocating pressure of Wang Qishan's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (CCDI) inspection teams that justifiably went into all the financial regulators and top financial firms after the stock market crash?

11:04 am
PM

The Chinese government desperately needs to restore confidence. Capital outflows have increased dramatically, good luck finding anyone in China who isn’t looking at their finances now with the expectation of RMB devaluation, and even diehard stock market boosters are having a hard time crafting coherent justifications that are convincing to even the greatest of fools.

PM

So what can Beijing do? Expect the taking of a symbolic scalp, likely that of Xiao Gang, chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), along with the embarrassing removal of the new stock market circuit-breaker. Perhaps Fang Xinghai, recently installed at the CSRC but still double-hatted with his position on the Central Leading Group for Financial and Economic Affairs, would be a good choice, but even those moves would be more symbolic than substantive.

PM

Will Xi see this mess as a political opportunity to be used to his advantage, especially now that we are well into the jockeying for the 19th Party Congress expected in late 2017, or will this mess be used against Xi? Premier Li Keqiang is at least titularly responsible for the economy, and there has been speculation growing for months that he will be gone at the 19th Party Congress. Perhaps he needs to go before then, to be replaced by Wang Qishan. I know, highly unlikely, but markets would probably love that move, both because Wang understands finance and economics and because such a reshuffling might spur hope that the corruption and discipline crackdown would ease.

11:04 am
PM

Li to go as well??

BE

What's on Xiao's tie? Bees? Are those bees?

BE

11:05 am
PM

I would not bet on such a move, and so long as Xi is making it clear that politics, not markets, are in command (政治挂帅), the odds increase that the upcoming Year of the Monkey will turn out to be the Year of the Bear.

PM

(done)

PM

Well spotted Bryce

11:05 am
BE

Those are bees, right? I know it's not the most important question, but in the Year of the Bear it's surely symbolic of .... something.

BE

Or monkey. Whatever.

PM

Monkey

11:06 am
BE

Anyway, the curiosity yesterday was why the market rallied on the news of the circuit breakers being retired.

PM

Command economy, innit

PM

China take

11:08 am
BE

Sure. But why does the Chinese market freezing and keeping things at the wrong price have any readthrough for other markets, which should be pricing themselves efficiently independently of what happens in China?

BE

(I like to torture myself with efficient market hypothesis occasionally. It's masochism, basically.)

undefined
11:09 am
PM

(Yes -- prize for the first Rabble member to properly identify the tie)

PM

(I have a copy of The Brain, the story of you, by David Eagleman on my desk, ready to post to the winner. Maybe)

Royal Dutch Shell’s £36bn bid for rival BG Group is poised to win the support of most of the Anglo-Dutch oil giant’s shareholders, paving the way for its completion despite a collapse in crude that has stoked fears the company is paying too much.
In a significant intervention, Institutional Shareholder Services, a proxy advisory body, is expected to recommend that investors support the deal, according to people familiar with the situation. ISS declined to comment.

11:11 am

So it really was a panic about nothing

PM

Or it was a panic about advisors earning their fees

BE

I say it's just risk averse markets. Arbs not prepared to wear a risk, having been steamrollered on half a dozen positions over the past 12 months.

11:12 am

that's true

BE

hmm

have they also been saying taht the deal maths work at $50 oil over two years?

BE

Yeah, I think that's all from the CFO's soiree to which we were NFI'd, as mentioned in yesterday's session.

11:15 am
PM

oh right

BE

Since we're here, Macquarie has rebased its forecasts this morning based on Brent at a "long-term normalised price" of .............. $74

BE

Which is down from $80. So I guess it's moving in the right direction.

11:17 am
BE

How much of this do you want me to share? I'm not sure on underlying value, given the disparity between forecast and spot.

PM

Give us a chunk

BE

we reiterate our conviction that the oil market will begin to rebalance in 2016 but also recognise the fact that in the interim, the market will continue to remain over-supplied. We revise down our oil price forecasts accordingly but remain optimistic in the longer run.
Our outlook for near-term oil and gas prices is therefore more cautious than before; we are
cutting our 2016 Brent forecast by 24%, with smaller but still significant reductions of 9% and 15% in 2017-18. Our long-term normalised price moves to US$74 from US$80.
We have also adjusted our natural gas price forecasts, taking Henry Hub down to an average of US$2.7/mmbtu in 2016, a fall of 11%, with an average cut of 14% in 2017-18. We have also reduced our European gas NBP forecast to US$5/mmbtu for the forecast period, in the expectation that the growing global LNG depresses spot prices in Europe.
The impact of these changes is fairly significant on our earnings and cashflow forecasts, as
we depict in the table below. Our average US$ EPS reduction in 2016 is 49% (31% ex PBR), with 11% and 22% falls in 2017-18. For cashflow, our DACF estimates fall by 13% in 2016 and 6% and 12% in 2017-18.

11:18 am
BE

BE

Versus market expectations, we are now on average 20% below consensus for 2016,
although a little above in 2017-18. Amongst the large caps, RDS stands out with our numbers 21% below cons, although this is for Shell standalone, which should be redundant from mid-February, assuming the BG acquisition is approved by shareholders this month. On Repsol we are 47% below cons, as expectations for a weaker refining environment do not seem to be fully reflected in market estimates as yet

BE

(@alewis2005: March rejig, and it depends on if anything's in #90 or above to push it out.)

Argument is that while it's not really in recovery mode yet, once it finds a recovery mode it'll trade at a premium to the sector.

11:24 am
BE

BE

The average PE is .... well, it's just Tesco, isn't it. So if Tesco trades at a premium to the average, the average will rise and .... oh, never mind.

BE

Here's the working.

11:25 am
BE

We think recent share price underperformance has left Tesco’s valuation at
attractive levels, although we remain conscious of the numerous headwinds facing
the UK food retail market. In particular, it now offers a reasonably visible doubledigit
FCF yield and is trading in-line with Sainsbury on an EV/sales basis for the first
time in many years. We also think that there are a number of likely helpful catalysts
in the coming months – with additional information at the FY results and in the
Annual Report helping earnings visibility and with the potential resolution of
several long-running distractions. Additionally, we tend to think that the upcoming
trading statement (14 January) may be less worrisome than the market’s worst
fears. Consequently we upgrade our stock rating to Overweight (from Equal
Weight), and our price target (reduced to £1.90 from £2.25, based on an average of
DCF and SOTP valuations) still gives a 34% upside potential.

BE

Valuation has reached attractive levels: Since its 1H results in October, Tesco has
underperformed the FTSE Allshare by 23pts, Sainsbury by 14ppts and Morrison by
12ppts. Our forecasts now imply a FCF yield of around 10% for the upcoming two years
and a similar EV/sales multiple to Sainsbury for the first time in our memory.

BE

Numerous potential catalysts: We expect that the FY results in April will bring more
colour on the cost saving opportunity (opex and pensions), together with some clarity
on guidance (margins and capex). The resetting of the management remuneration
targets to adjust for the Korean disposal should also give more insight into the potential
margin upside. We also expect the resolution of several long running distractions.

11:26 am
BE

The distractions are settling the US class actions, two of which have been settled and one's outstanding ....

BE

The SFO investigation into the profit overstatement. .....

BE

... and the Groceries Code Adjudicator investigating potential breaches of the Supply Code of Practice

11:26 am
PM

Those are certainly distractions

BE

None of which looks big whoop, from an equity point of view. But I guess every little .... sorry, I won't do that. It's cliche'd.

BE

Risks certainly remain . . . The threat of the discounters to the UK supermarket sector
remains clear – although we believe recent market share data provides a little room for
encouragement. The potential upwards pressure from the Living Wage remains,
although we do not expect a visible impact in the near future.

11:27 am
BE

But other factors may turn in Tesco’s favour . . . UK food deflation may start to ease
off in 2016, supermarket spending may show more benefit from falling fuel prices and
discount rates may help erode Tesco’s pension deficit. There are no guarantees on any
of these points but we tend to think the risk profile is tilted in Tesco’s favour.

BE

So that's that.

So. From potentially the first trillion-dollar company, to Sports Direct.

BE

A rather terse profit warning just crossed the tape.

BE

Since our interim results on 10 December 2015, we have seen a deterioration of trading conditions on the high street and a continuation of the unseasonal weather over the key Christmas period. As a result, we are no longer confident of meeting our adjusted underlying EBITDA target (before share scheme costs) of £420m for the full year. In light of these factors, and in anticipation of similar trading conditions between now and the end of April, management's current expectation for the full year is for adjusted underlying EBITDA (before share scheme costs) of between £380m and £420m.

Here's the aramco statement

PM

Saudi Aramco confirms that it has been studying various options to allow broad public participation in its equity through the listing in the capital markets of an appropriate percentage of the Company’s shares and/or the listing of a bundle its downstream subsidiaries.
Once the study of these various options is complete, the findings will be presented to the Company’s Board of Directors which will make its recommendations to the Saudi Aramco Supreme Council.
This proposal is consistent with the broad and progressive direction pursued by the Kingdom for reforms, including privatization in various sectors of the Saudi economy and deregulation of markets, which the Company strongly supports.
Saudi Aramco would like to emphasize that this process will strengthen the Company's focus on its long term vision of becoming the world’s leading energy and chemical enterprise. This includes prudently managing the Kingdom’s hydrocarbon resources, adding value across the value chain, reliably meeting its customers’ demand, and meeting its stakeholder and environmental commitments.

11:43 am
BE

In the meantime, here's Peel Hunt.

BE

H1 results. Profits were flat in actual currency at £6.3m on a 2.2% reduction in
sales. This combined an £0.8m improvement in royalty income, offset by a
similar reduction in core business profitability. In constant currency sales rose
0.7% and core business profits increased by £0.1m. Trade (+1.4%) and Mail
Order (+5.3%) were both ahead of last year in constant currency, with Retail
down 2%. Within Retail, Europe is particularly weak and the company is taking
action by accelerating replacement of store managers. It will take time for the
new managers to turn round performance.
The gross margin improved by 60bps to 69.6% and operating expenses increased
by £0.3m because of an increase in the store base. There were 25 new store
openings and 13 closures, leaving the number of stores at 430 at period-end. The
full-year tax charge is expected to be 24%, vs prior expectations of 26%.

BE

A disappointing Christmas. Sales were weaker than last year, largely as a result
of a tough comparison. The company will struggle to recover the lost sales in the
remainder of the period: hence the reduction in full-year profit expectations.
Nonetheless, there is plenty of positive momentum in the business, and this
should become increasingly apparent.

11:44 am
BE

Plenty to look forward to. Management is progressing a number of initiatives
that will become increasingly apparent next year, albeit the level of impact is
unclear currently. Importantly the number of new stores is accelerating (+c30 in
the full year), with growth in most markets, but particularly marked in the US.
The benefit to sales will become more obvious next year. There are also a number
of product initiatives, with a range created to target toy stores as well as the larger
retailers. GAW has also announced that it will bring back some old favourites,
which will delight its loyal fan base. On the royalty side, there is a growing list of
tablet and computer games, as well as board games. Royalty income will
inevitably be lumpy, but should be significantly higher than in recent years.
New forecasts. We are reducing our FY2016E from £17.5m to £16.0m (EPS
37.7p from 40.2p) and FY2017E from £18.5m to £17.0m (EPS 40.1p from
42.3p). Our dividend forecast is unchanged.

BE

Recommendation. The last month may have seen disappointing trading, but
there is significant change happening at Games Workshop, and this should
deliver stronger sales growth. The improvement in gross margin should ensure
this is translated into higher core business profits as well as cash generation. We
see any share price weakness as a good buying opportunity.

BE

Do I need to say here that Peel Hunt's broker to Games Workshop?

11:54 am
PM

David Lock there trying to catch his target price up with reality

PM

Cut from 918p to 510p but he's still saying "hold"

PM

Near term visibility on earnings is poor

This note takes a detailed look at Standard Chartered’s recent strategy update. We think the RoE targets (8% in 2018, 10% in 2020) imply earnings of $4.3-4.5bn in 2018 and $5.6-5.9bn in 2020. Though the RoE target is low vs. peers & history, we do not think it unambitious: implying 18% improvement in revenues vs annualized 3Q15 levels. In the next 3 years StanChart will need to generate greater avg RoE of 3-6% to pay dividends, which could prove challenging during a restructuring phase. We think it too early to turn Buyers, and we retain our Hold rating. Our TP falls to 510p(918p) and EPS falls materially.

11:55 am
PM

Watch the revenues not just the impairments line

Whilst impairments and commodity exposures dominate near-term concerns and capital debate, what is most important for the medium-term outlook for SC is revenues. Income has been in decline since 1H14, 3Q15 marked a new low, and the 2018 and 2020 plans imply growth in revenues whilst simultaneously cutting US$36bn of RWAs, and reducing costs. Though we think the refocus of StanChart away from higher risk assets, and on productivity and efficiency gains is welcome, we have seen few banks achieve an improvement in revenues whilst reducing costs and RWAs – it is likely that revenues will fall faster in the near-term than costs. DBe are 21% lower than the implied 2018 earnings, driven principally by revenues 5% lower than implied. Every 1% better / worse revenues vs. 2018 forecasts equates to around 4% on EPS and TP.

PM

I'd prefer to stay focused on impairments, actually

PM

Capital appears sufficient for now, but normalization of dividend unlikely

Capital (13% 3Q15 pro-forma) now appears sufficient following the US$5.1bn capital raise (barring significantly higher impairments than expected). We forecast CET1 to remain around 12.7%. But the implied regulatory headwinds of ~US$90bn RWAs and restructuring costs need to be absorbed by underlying earnings in the next 3 years, which leaves limited room for a return to a normalized dividend payout ratio in the near term unless regulatory headwinds from Basel 4 / IFRS9 are lower than expected.

11:56 am
PM

Valuation and Risks; TP falls to 510p, Hold recommendation

SC is currently trading at c.5.5x-5.8x implied 2018 earnings – optically cheap, but for good reason we believe given the lack of visibility on earnings (on DB est. SC is on 9.6x 2017 EPS). SC is due to change its divisional reporting in 2016, we thus use a GGM approach rather than SoTP for deriving our TP of 510p (918p previously). Given limited upside, and lack of near-term earnings visibility we retain our Hold recommendation. Our EPS est. are reduced materially for 2015-17 and we extend forecasts to 2018. Upside risks are better capital formation, a bid for Standard Chartered, or significant improvement in EM growth & commodity price prospects leading to improved impairment and revenue outlook. Downside risks: deterioration in asset quality, slower EM growth, weaker commodity prices, higher regulatory requirements & a weaker revenue environment.

PM

Upside is a bid?

PM

Well, yes

11:56 am
undefined
BE

There was a request for Vectura earlier. Happy to help.

BE

US partner named as Roxane -- as in, soon to be Hikma

11:57 am
BE

Also a US trial of its generic Advair completed.

BE

Finncap can talk us through the detail better than I can.

BE

Vectura announced today the completion of a clinical trial for VR315 (a generic Advair for asthma/COPD) in the US and confirmed that its partner for this programme and VR506 US (a generic, inhaled corticosteroid monotherapy for asthma) is Roxane Laboratories, a subsidiary of Boehringer Ingelheim. Roxane Laboratories is responsible for development, manufacturing and commercialisation of both products in the US. To date, Vectura has announced development milestones under the VR315 agreement totalling US$12.0m. In addition, Vectura is eligible to receive a further US$23.0m upon achievement of future pre-determined development milestones on VR315 (e.g. submission of a file to FDA, regulatory approval, first sale of the product), as well as a royalty from all sales of VR315 in the US (our model assumes a 15.0% royalty rate). We expect approval and launch of VR315 in the second half of the next financial year, shortly after Advair’s patent expiry in H2 CY2016E. We make no changes to our forecasts and maintain our 225 target price.

PM

Can you imagine selling shares in Saudi Aramco?
This is something that is being reviewed, and we believe a decision will be made over the next few months. Personally I’m enthusiastic about this step. I believe it is in the interest of the Saudi market, and it is in the interest of Aramco, and it is for the interest of more transparency, and to counter corruption, if any, that may be circling around Aramco.
